summary: This document is an email chain between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing negotiations and legal strategy regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case. It focuses on the selection of a special master or attorney to represent multiple victims, concerns about a prior agreement, and mentions media and defense attorney actions.

events.title: Internal Prosecution Strategy Discussion
events.description: U.S. Attorney's Office staff exchange emails discussing concerns about victim representation agreements, the role of Judge Davis, and defense attorney actions.

locations: 1395 Brickell Avenue, Miami, Florida 33131-3302 (Fowler White Burnett P.A. office)
keyFacts: Prosecutors express concern about being 'triple-teamed' by many people on the other side, indicating a contentious legal environment.
The New York Post reported that defense attorney Gerry Lefcourt was writing to 'Alex' (likely then-U.S. Attorney Alexander Acosta) to reconsider sex offender registration for Epstein.

There is significant internal debate about the appropriateness of having Judge Davis serve as both fact-finder and representative for up to 40 scattered victims, with concerns raised about his health.
The email discusses a waiver in an agreement that allegedly only applies if victims agree to be bound by a settlement procedure, contradicting the ability to 'file suit pursuant to 2255.'
The reappearance of an individual named 'Guy' in the case is noted as a factor that may make Judge Davis 'no longer be the best choice' for a role.
